title: 110_hr1307
content:
The "Veterans Identity Protection Act" or "VIP Act" aims to reimburse individuals for injuries resulting from unauthorized use of information from the Department of Veterans Affairs and expedite the settlement of claims for these injuries. The "Veterans Identity Protection Act" defines key terms such as Director and Injured person, who are individuals affected by data breaches at the Department of Veterans Affairs. The "Office" refers to the Office of Veterans Identity Protection Claims established under section 4(a) for individuals affected by data breaches at the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Office of Veterans Identity Protection Claims was established under section 4(a) for individuals affected by data breaches at the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Office of Veterans Identity Protection Claims, established under section 4(a), is an independent office of the executive branch to process and pay claims. The President appoints a director to investigate and determine money damages claims. The office is funded from allocated funds, can reimburse other agencies for support, appoint temporary personnel, and request assistance from other federal departments. The Office of Veterans Identity Protection Claims, an independent office, can request personnel from other federal departments to assist in carrying out its duties. SEC. 5. REIMBURSEMENT FOR INJURIES SUFFERED. Each injured person is entitled to reimbursement for injuries resulting from unauthorized use of personal information and damages determined by the Director. Claims must be submitted within 2 years of regulations being promulgated. State laws apply to calculating damages, limited to actual compensatory damages. The Director determines and fixes the amount to be paid for a claim under the Act within 180 days. Payments are limited to actual compensatory damages for injuries suffered and do not include punitive damages. The Director may make advance or partial payments to a claimant upon request before the final settlement of a claim. The amount to be paid for a claim is determined within 180 days and is limited to actual compensatory damages, excluding punitive damages. Additionally, any payments or settlements made to the injured person with respect to the claim will be deducted from the final settlement amount to prevent overrecovery by the claimant. The Director may make advance or partial payments before the final settlement of a claim. If a claimant receives a partial payment but further payment is denied, they can seek judicial review and keep the partial payment unless ineligible or fraudulent. Allowable damages for a claim paid under this Act may include uncompensated losses. The Act allows for reimbursement of uncompensated damages for loss of property, business, or financial loss due to unauthorized use of personal information. Acceptance of payment under the Act releases all claims against the United States related to the same subject matter. The Act allows for reimbursement of damages for loss due to unauthorized use of personal information. Acceptance of payment releases all claims against the United States related to the same subject matter. The Director must publish regulations for processing and payment of claims within 45 days of the Act's enactment. Additionally, the Director must provide clear explanations in newspapers in English and Spanish. The Director must provide clear explanations of rights and regulations under the Act in English and Spanish through various media channels. Consultation with relevant authorities is required for efficient claims administration and addressing local concerns. An injured person may elect to seek reimbursement for injuries resulting from unauthorized use of personal information by submitting a claim under this Act, filing a claim under chapter 171 of title 28, or bringing a civil action under any other law. The election of remedy is final and conclusive on all related injuries. The Director will establish arbitration procedures for settling disputes related to claims for injuries resulting from unauthorized use of personal information. Injured individuals can choose to settle their claims through arbitration, which will have a binding effect and preclude judicial review. The Director will establish arbitration procedures for settling disputes related to claims for injuries resulting from unauthorized use of personal information. Injured individuals can choose to settle their claims through arbitration, which will be binding and preclude judicial review. This Act does not affect the right of claimants to file for benefits under any Federal entitlement program. Claimants aggrieved by a final decision of the Director can bring a civil action in a United States District Court within 60 days to modify or set aside the decision. The court will hear the action based on the record before the Director, and the decision will be upheld if supported by substantial evidence. Attorney's and agent's fees are also addressed. The Director's findings will be upheld if supported by substantial evidence. Attorneys and agents cannot charge fees exceeding 10% of the claim payment, with a fine of up to $10,000 for violations. Debt collection requirements under title 31, United States Code, do not apply to payments under this Act. SEC. 6. REPORT; AUDIT.

The Director must submit a report every six months detailing claims under the Act, including amount claimed, nature of claim, and claim status. The Comptroller General will conduct an annual audit on claim payments. SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Sums are authorized to be appropriated to the Director as necessary to carry out the Act, remaining available until expended.
